reviewText:
I own Audiosurf 1 and decided to get the second mainly because of the updatd graphics and customisation the new version offers. There have been some changes though, and not all of them are good.

GOOD ASPECTS

The changes to the graphics is really nice, as the limited options in the first game got a bit stale after a while.

I love audiosprint, which is something that I wasn't even aware of until I opened the game up. It's a whole new experience ccompared to the regular game, and that is a very good thing.

Apparently the UI used to be terrible and was changed- the current one is quite good, making it possible to swap between modes and skins without being clunky.


BAD ASPECTS

Wakeboard. This is the ultimate in an idea that sounds good but really doesn't work in practice. I can't see myself using it.

Different skins seem to all have their own scoreboards. This is incredibly disappointing. I can understand mods that can affect how the game works doing this, but why skins as well? Maybe it will be changed when the game eventually is released.

How blocks are placed and their density has been changed. I understand why it was done- there were a lot of complaints that songs with large uphill parts were quite boring due to the low block densities they have. However it's gone too far the other way, where the placement of the blocks seem to have little correlation with the music, and the main thing the music influences being the track slope. This is disappointing, as it feels less like I'm riding my music and more playing a puzzle game with my music in the background.


Overall it is an enjoyable game, with my biggest gripe being the fiddling around with the block placement.

EDIT: OK so this is much later, and I'm coming to enjoy the game more. The ability to add mew modes is great and the changes they made to Audiosprint were good. The issues I had with the early access version aren't in the final version, especially regarding block placement. I maintain that it's superior to the first game, especially in the little details like layout and so forth.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI'm sorry, but I cannot recommend this game as it currently stands, and while the original Audiosurf is available for purchase. Sure this game has nicer graphics and Workshop support for different skins,  it is extremely crippled due to the worse mechanics on some of the major characters. When I first booted up the game it crashed and I dismissed it as being a bug since it is an Early Access game, but then I booted it up a second time and once I chose my song it crashed and locked my computer up for at least five minutes. When it unfroze I booted it up one more time and played two rounds in it. Pointman is extremely broken this time around. If you overfill you get no score deducted. Also sometimes when you go to pick up a block or a power-up, it won't pick up. Also at the end of the round there was no high-score table which is a feature they might not have implemented yet. If you are not sure if you should put towards the extra dollars for this title don't at the moment. They may fix this and make it better but as it is, don't go for it and just get the first game.
voteText: 4 of 10 people (40%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I enjoyed the original Audiosurf much more than I enjoyed this one.

The gameplay of Audiosurf 2 is not horrible but it doesn't live up to the original. It can be confusing when you switch from playing the first game to this one because even though the basics are the same, they are very much different in gameplay.

The menus are the greatest challenge of this game in my opinion, and the most annoying.
The orignal Audiosurf had nice and simple menus that were easy to navigate. This game however, the menus at first are very confusing and you can easily get stuck trying to find your actual music. If you select the wrong folder, you can't simply go back to the previous folder, you have to click out into a new menu and then go back to the song menu and start from the drives.
Another thing that bugged me and quite possibly bugged me the most, was changing options during the game.
Audiosurf 1 let you simply pause during a game to change your options, like mouse sensitivity, sound effects, volume and ect...
In Audiosurf 2, you can't pause during the game, change the settings, and resume the game where you left off. (At least I've never found a way).
This is incredibly annoying especially when you want to fine tune your mouse sensitivity and have to go back to the main menu and go through finding your song all over again. Then you need to repeat several times just so you can get your sensitivity to your desire.

Compared to the original, the function of hitting cars (Cubes) is, in my opinion, terrible. It's hard to tell where you actually are able to hit the cars and you can't simply do a wrist flick to quickly move through greys (as mono) since they're always packed tightly. In Audiosurf 1, it was easy to figure out where the cars can be hit and that would allow you to know where you can sneak as mono to avoid greys like a ninja. Audiosurf 2 just doesn't allow that.


Overall, I do not think the game is bad, it just needs more tweaks. It's been in early access for a while now and I still can't enjoy it myself.
I would not recommend you buy this game just yet, but I would implore you to check out the original Audiosurf if you haven't already. The creators of this game are amazing and I know they can make this game just as amazing as the original with time.

reviewText:
I heard some great things about audiosurf when I was searching for music games. I really wanted to like this game but it just has very few redeeming qualities compared to other music games out there (some of which are completely free...). That being said, it's probably the best music game on steam currently, but it's not a great achievement since I have found every single music game out on steam to be less than 3/10 at best.
Just play Osu! or something.

A game with no substance as of current. 2/10 and worth about £3 - not £11.

Lacks in gameplay. Notes (and the main tempo) are usually completely off time, not present or just spammed when nothing is happening - ruining basically any shred of capability this game had of being a decent music game. It's just a badly timed game with music on the top. If the game isn't in time with the actual music in your MUSIC GAME then I could just play any other game and listen to my personal playlist to get the same effect. This renders this game absolutely pointless.
I only enjoy the game when it actually picks up contrast of a silent part to a chorus. That's not enjoyment, that's just me thinking wow they didn't actually mess up this game that badly!" which is the only thing that came from this game that amused me. So it's not a rhythm game

hoursPlayed: if I wanted a visual spectacle music game I'd watch videos of Sound Voltex III.\nSo yeah

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game isn't better then the first one, there are different aspects of it that you may enjoy more or less due to workshop support and a new mode, but it still isn't better. I bought this game 12 or so months ago and it's still in early acsess.

Pros:
-Workshop support
- Relaxing and fun way to listen to music
- Pretty style of graphics

Cons:
- Not better then the last game
- Menu options aren't as good as the previous game
- Previous game is more fun
- Does not build on anything from the first game
- Has been in early access for a very long time (probably abandonded)

Recommendation - don't get this game unless you really love Audio Surf and want it to be slightly different because you play the first one too much. If you haven't played Audio Surf 1, then go get that instead because that is fantastic.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Audiosurf 1 was the reason I downloaded Steam years ago. I was very hyped when AS2 came out and I got the pre-beta release immediately. It's a sad conclusion that after months of tweaking the game, AS2 still suffers from development issues. There is still no pop up file browser, which makes finding that one song you wanna play impossible to find. The Workshop is doing a decent job so far but sadly this game isn't THAT popular which results in not a lot of Workshop mods that are worth your time. I'm still a big fan of AS and I come back to it from time to time, the game has a nack for giving an extra dimension to the way you listen to your favorite music. I can recommend AS2 for sure, but it's probably better to get AS1 since that game works like a charm and AS2 basically offers more of the same. The tweaked graphics and (lame) new game mode don't really make AS2 worth while. Not yet at least. I'm still hoping for the developers and Workshop fanatics to turn this sequal in a great game.

I wrote this 1.5 years ago and not much has changed ever since. This is a complete joke, you can't rake in money for a game that's literally YEARS from being a finished product. It feels like I've been conned. This game is still not finished, it's just not fully functional. It still doesn't have a pop-up file browser, it still doesn't have last.fm enabled, the menus have been tweaked but why is everything so small? I have been playing AS1 a lot more than this, this is just not good enough.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a far cry from the original Audiosurf. They have altered all of the game modes included so far, and have sullied the Mono mode so badly, that they do not even include a Stealth finish on the most popular and widely played mode of the original.

I do not see myself being the only player to find this to be utterly egregious and unacceptable. I could not reccoment this game to anyone who enjoyed and like the original.

On the plus sides, they have stripped the minimalistic and tubular graphics and replaced them with some kind of 3D mess they call an improvement. Fantastic

Also, they have removed the blocks from most of the modes and replaced them with what looks like footballs and spikey things. Lovely.

If they release future updates reconciling these errors, then I will alter and update my review... until then. BOOOOOO!

reviewText:
I can't, with a good conscience, recommend this game. It's like a built up, stripped down version of the first one. It has a lot of new features, mostly online music integration, but almost nothing has changed gameplay wise and the menus look terrible.

I played at a friends during Early Access and saw how the menu was a mess, and now thinking that they're better now at release. Nope. They still look like they were done by someone who has just begun their first course in GUI Design in college. Compare the menu of this game to Audiosurf 1 and there's a tremendous difference in quality.

My thinking is; why didn't they just add these things to the first Audiosurf? It would clearly have been the better choice.

+Online music integration (SoundCloud etc. etc.)
+Visually interesting (depends on taste)
+Steam Workshop integration
+More stable scoreboards

-Looks incomplete at full release (Menus are a mess, no track info as Audiosurf 1 had)
-Gameplay wise no changes to the first game(excluding game modes)
-Bad hit detection (might just be me and my eyes though)
-Unreachable block in mono (just a nitpick)

Summary: Audiosurf 1 is better in almost every regard. Would've been better to add the new features of this to the first game instead.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Audiosurf 2; where you have the option to go on a musical mind trip without ever using drugs.
On a more serious note, Audiosurf 2 is better, in a few ways, than the original Audiosurf.

The graphics and other visuals have become much better, and the option to have different skins is really neat. So far there are a few skins default in the game, of which i cant really explain, but the base skin would be the one in the screenshots on the store page. The UI is also improved, giving it a more aesthetically pleasing look (imo), and makes browsing for music a little bit easier and cleaner. Workshop support allows people to create their own skins and some of the skins I've seen are pretty good, so that adds to the visual diversity. It would, however, still need a lot more work to iron out some bugs/glitches and other minor gripes with the menu, integration with other services (i.e. SoundCloud), etc.

The gameplay remains largely unchanged, at least from what I have noticed, and is still a fun, yet, somewhat challenging experience in some cases. Gamemodes are few in number compared to the original, but the the one's which are currently in the game are Mono, Pointman, Pusher, etc., along with a new gamemode called Wakeboard where you basically build up a combo, catch some air, do some tricks, and build up points that way. Personally, I don't care much for the new mode, but I feel like adding new gamemodes shows that the developer does care about the game, at least a bit. The added workshop support allows people to create their own gamemodes as well, from slight alterations to main gamemodes like Mono, to new modes altogether. Also, grey blocks, or what seem to be distorted sound bars in the lanes, dont add a block to your lanes, but rather they remove one block for each that you hit. Again, there are many things which could use some fixing, and ironing out but it's in Early Access, what can you expect.

Things I would like to see get added are more of the old versions of different gamemodes, like Ninja Mono, or Double Vision, and although im sure there is a DV in the workshop, an official version would be nice as well. Some of the different settings we could change from the menu when hitting Escape while playing, such as the different sounds for hitting notes/blocks/whatever you call them, or changing the background effects, like inverting colours, or adding a paint effect to everything.

tl:dr

Overall, Audiosurf 2 is a great game as is, even in Early Access, and is well worth the money. A worthy successor to the original, and you should get it if you haven't played the original, or this one. (Apologies if info was left out, don't make reviews often)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Audiosurf 2; where you have the option to go on a musical mind trip without ever using drugs.
On a more serious note, Audiosurf 2 is better, in a few ways, than the original Audiosurf.

The graphics and other visuals have become much better, and the option to have different skins is really neat. So far there are a few skins default in the game, of which i cant really explain, but the base skin would be the one in the screenshots on the store page. The UI is also improved, giving it a more aesthetically pleasing look (imo), and makes browsing for music a little bit easier and cleaner. Workshop support allows people to create their own skins and some of the skins I've seen are pretty good, so that adds to the visual diversity. It would, however, still need a lot more work to iron out some bugs/glitches and other minor gripes with the menu, integration with other services (i.e. SoundCloud), etc.

The gameplay remains largely unchanged, at least from what I have noticed, and is still a fun, yet, somewhat challenging experience in some cases. Gamemodes are few in number compared to the original, but the the one's which are currently in the game are Mono, Pointman, Pusher, etc., along with a new gamemode called Wakeboard where you basically build up a combo, catch some air, do some tricks, and build up points that way. Personally, I don't care much for the new mode, but I feel like adding new gamemodes shows that the developer does care about the game, at least a bit. The added workshop support allows people to create their own gamemodes as well, from slight alterations to main gamemodes like Mono, to new modes altogether. Also, grey blocks, or what seem to be distorted sound bars in the lanes, dont add a block to your lanes, but rather they remove one block for each that you hit. Again, there are many things which could use some fixing, and ironing out but it's in Early Access, what can you expect.

Things I would like to see get added are more of the old versions of different gamemodes, like Ninja Mono, or Double Vision, and although im sure there is a DV in the workshop, an official version would be nice as well. Some of the different settings we could change from the menu when hitting Escape while playing, such as the different sounds for hitting notes/blocks/whatever you call them, or changing the background effects, like inverting colours, or adding a paint effect to everything.

tl:dr

Overall, Audiosurf 2 is a great game as is, even in Early Access, and is well worth the money. A worthy successor to the original, and you should get it if you haven't played the original, or this one. (Apologies if info was left out, don't make reviews often)

Early Access Review

Dethrone update fixes a TON of bugs. The game looks and feels much better.
Compared to Audiosurf 1, mono in this game is actually fun and rewarding. Not to mention, with Dethrone update, it's even more reactive to music changes. I cannot wait for the full version release of this game, already a big step up from Audiosurf 1.

EDIT: Picking this up after a while, and one thing I don't like: There's no control over gamepad vibration, nor any way to turn it completely off. Come on, not everyone likes the darned thing vibrating throughout the entire song. It's highly distracting, not to mention annoying because it uses 100% force instead of mild vibrations.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Late 2013: I get in early and find a game with rough visuals and weird game modes. I play for 20 minutes and think meh...".

Summer 2014: I go back
date: and find something completely different. The graphics render much better and things look as impressively shiny as the original made back when it was new. The recently added Stadium skin is gorgeous and the reactive blocks makes it pop in a convincing way.\n\nAnd
recommended: while the developer is working on taking game modes in new directions the Workshop has an assortment of recreations and variations on old modes as well as its own experiments. The major drawback is that the amount of mods fragments the scoreboards
hoursPlayed: but that will probably change as the community finds favorites.\n\nThe first Audiosurf was a bit rough around the edges and this still has a bit to go before getting there. But it's hihgly playable at this point
voteText: and development seems to be moving along steadily enough that I'm glad I supported it from the start."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

At first I was a bit disappointed at the game; it seemed like movement was sluggish and collisions were kinda dodgy, and it felt a  lot easier as a whole than the original Audiosurf. The wakeboarding mode wasn't really all that great, and the default skins that came with the game were just okay.

While I did fix the movement by doubling the mouse sensitivity, essentially, the workshop saves this game. There are plenty of really fun community modes and quite a few skins that are absolutely gorgeous (my favorite so far is  Hyperdrive 2  , which is stunning).

Without the workshop I couldn't recommend it, at least not at this price. With it, it's not quite a must buy, but it's not exactly a waste of money, and if you like the first game, it's probably worth checking out.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I got AudioSurf 2 at a slightly discounted price around last Christmas, and fell in love with it almost immediately. It fills a niche in my gaming library that very few of my other favorite games can, and here's why:

- I can play it anywhere I bring my laptop
- Installing mods is clean and low-maintenence
- It boots up and exits out quickly and cleanly
- Unless you're installing mods, it doesn't need an internet connection
- It has great music (LOL)
- It delivers a satisfying gameplay experience, and most importantly
- It's incredibly easy to pick up and play, and just as easy to put down and transition to stuff that needs doing in real life

AudioSurf 2 is the perfect game for a person on the move, who needs to play games to get through the day but whose schedule doesn't allow for long sessions of Skyrim, Garry's Mod, Minecraft, or other games they love. I realize this is the main draw of casual gaming, and while some gamers may see casual gaming as a synonym for low-quality tripe
date:
I assure you this is not the case.

If you're looking for depth and complexity, this isn't the game for you. But if you're looking to kill some time between classes or meetings, AudioSurf 2 is as good as it gets.

I'm gonna go play some more now. You should too.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI DO recommend this game, but it has its ups and downs from the first game in my opinion. Im going to start with the positive stuff. The graphics are absolutely outstanding, and improves on the first game for sure. The graphics are colorful, fast, and pretty. Another up is that skins, and mods were never easier and more convenient. I was able to get tons of skins for the game and instantly use them, which was amazing! The new wakeboard mode is unique, and adds an epic feeling to a song. In wakeboard mode you can literally surf to your music, try to get high air, and pull off some sick tricks. I love playing wakeboard mode when I'm in for something new. Now for the negative stuff. (Now remember this game is still in early access). The game can be slightly laggy at times. This CAN be fixed, but if you want a non-laggy game you will most likely have to play on the lowest graphic quality. And the only other thing I dislike about it is that finding your own music to surf to is surprisingly difficult. I don't  know if there is an easier way to find your music, (if there is tell me) but the only way I found my music was going into recent songs
date: and it would show a list of songs that I've recently played in Audiosurf 1. Besides that, the game is absolutely stunning. The game is still in early access, so I'm going to give the game time to get better. For an early access game: 9/10. I highly recommend this game!

10/10. Only time I ever listened to Nickleback.


Okay, but for serious:
Played the hell out of the first one (70 hours). The simple gameplay in conjunction with your library of music is addicting and enjoyable to an endless degree. If it ever gets boring, try a new song, a new genre, PLAY A PODCAST. That's right. Any MP3 you have on your computer can be played through Audiosurf 2, and that means the gameplay stays fresh as long as there is good music still out there.

In addition to the vanilla gamemodes and skins, there is a large library of user-created modifications available via the Workshop which I HIGHLY recommend you check out.

Great game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I loved audiosurf 1 and when I saw audiosurf 2 was in early access I instantly wanted to get it so in my personal opinion if you like music games like DDR, Dj hero, or guitar hero then get this.

About Game
If you don't know what audioSurf is about is basicaly you pick a song from your Pc or the song of the day and then it will generate a track ocording to the song and the speed of you'r ship or whatever will depend of the tempo of the song. Now it may sound boring but when you play your favorite song on this you'll think it is epic.

Gamemodes
The game has manny official modes and community ones like Mono or WakeBoard to name a few and there is some new added every week or so. Each made has its own unique play style and each can be challenging in its own way.

Skins
There are many default skins and also there are lots of skins being uploaded to the community which is great in my opinion. Now if you don't know what the skins do they basicly can change the whole look of the tracks which is great also in my opinion.

Personal Rating 9.5/10
Professional Rating 8.6/10

In conclusion if you like music based games like DDR,DJHero,Or Guitar Hero then you'll love this game. Also keep in mind this is an early access game which means it has some glitches but no gamebreaking ones that I have seen.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Audiosurf 2 is a must for any music lover. The game is simple: pick a song stored on your iTunes or anywhere you store music, and the game will create a track for you to ride on that bumps, dips, and drops to the song.

It's insanely easy to pick up, but with plenty of difficulty to keep you sticking around for higher scores against other players who have played the same song. Replayability is excellent, I've spent up to 2 hours playing tracks from songs in my library trying to find what song is the most intense and what song is the most mellow. There are different modes of play, from the simple Mono" that has you pick up colored blocks on the track while avoiding grey blocks to the new "Wakeboard" modes that swap your ship for a wakeboarder who pulls off tricks and flips off of the hills created in your track.

Now why would you get Audiosurf 2 instead of Audiosurf 1? Audiosurf 1 is still a great game with all of the same strengths mentioned above
date: why not just go with the original? One word: Workshop. The Steam Workshop support for Audiosurf 2 makes sure that you never get bored with the game. Sick of looking at the same neon tracks? Subscribe to a skin mod. Mono Turbo not fast enough for you? Subscribe to a gametype mod. The Steam Workshop makes getting new skins and gametypes so easy it's dumb.\n\nAnother new feature in Audiosurf 2 is to play songs from artists that you follow on SoundCloud directly; you don't need to download it to your computer. I personally haven't used this feature yet
recommended: but it's still great to have for people who want to spend the time to download before you play.\n\nWhile this game is still in development

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nEven though this game is still in beta it is easily one of my favourite games at the moment. Audiosurf 2 is the second game in the Audiosurf series (if you couldn't guess that) and they have stepped-up their game immaculately! If you are not familiar with the Audiosurf games let me give a quick explanation. In Audiosurf you ride" your music by controlling a weird space-themed vehicle. You must hit and "collect" blocks to score points. There are various game modes which alter the rules slightly and have unique gimmicks which add a nice variety. A new addition to Audiosurf 2 is the new "Wakeboard" mode where you try to hit "waves" and get big air in which you can do cool and flashy stunts in. The game will let you choose a song to play from your own music collection and will auto-generate a level for you to play. The graphics are really suitable
date: cool colours for build-ups and hot pulsating colours for the intense drops! And incase you weren't too fond of the colour scheme you have the option to choose from a variety of skins. ALSO if that wasn't enough you can now use various (user created) workshop skins! Overall this game has a lot of pros and very little in the way of cons (I can't name any off the top of my head) and the game hasn't even been released yet! The graphics and effects really help you to immerse yourself within the game and the colour scheme lets you know exactly what part of the song it is and how the level will unfold. Leaderboards are also available for bragging rights (I've already bragged on my facebook account :3) and to show off infront of your mates! Well cya later I'm off to ride my music into victory!!"

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nWhoa. Audiosurf's an outstanding game, but Audiosurf 2 appears to be better in just about every way. Race through levels generated from your own music, or play tunes from an ever-changing song list that the game pulls from the Internet. Do not play this game if you get any kind of motion sickness or such, but if you can handle it, Audiosurf 2 will deliver with some outstanding visuals and trippy behavior. User mods are well supported by the game, and can completely change how it plays. I just flew through an asteroid field, for example. The developer's extremely active with new content, rules changes, and bug smashings, and this early access game plays like a dream already. Get it!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Nearly there.

Audiosurf 2 is what I wanted it to be, sporting better graphics and the truly revolutionary modding system (which I have enjoyed using), allowing you to install mods that completely change gameplay, as well as skins which change the look of the game.

Thankfully a lot of the UI glitches that plagues the game early on have been rectified, but there are still some issues, so if you want something with tons of polish, you should hold back.

Also, unfortunately, last.fm scrobbling support is yet to arrive, which for compulsive scrobblers like myself, is a pain in the posterior. EDIT: Last.fm support has now arrived, but it involves creating a file (with a text editor, this cannot be done within the game at present) with your username and password stored in plaintext. I was hoping for a more elegant solution.

Back to the positive though - gameplay is as smooth as ever, and the new wakeboarding mode (spoiler: you 'jump' before intense sections of track, then glide down whilst doing tricks) is a lot of fun, although it will require you to pick different types of track (ones with varying intensity, as all fast or all slow is no good).

There are also scoreboards so you can smack the excrement out of your friends and other Steam users with your performance on Justin Bieber tunes. Just be careful because these leaderboards sometime wiped between updates (RIP my Daft Punk highscore).

Overall I think it's gr8 (perhaps because my talent is inn8). I r8 8/8 m8 and I eagerly aw8 the next upd8.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has amazing potential in the future for skin modding as well as custom game modes. If you have a lot of music, and enjoy listening to it while interacting with it, this game is for you. The way the game syncs up with your music is simply astounding and is a huge upgrade from the first game. even if you don't have a lot of music on your computer, there is an audiosurf radio that supplies music. Not to mention there is soundcloud support so you can find an music you want without the need to download! The way you can be turned off from this game is if you don't have a lot of music or a supply of new music.

Even if you just enjoy modding lua coding files, this game makes it easy to custom your experience anyway you want!
